text: There was a man from Ramathaim Zophim, from the hill country of Ephraim. His name was Elkanah. He was the son of Jeroham, the son of Elihu, the son of Tohu, the son of Zuph, an Ephraimite.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had two wives; the name of the first was Hannah and the name of the second was Peninnah. Peninnah had children, but Hannah had no children.
speaker: Narrator

text: This man would go up from his city year after year to worship and to sacrifice to the Lord of Heaven’s Armies at Shiloh. (It was there that the two sons of Eli, Hophni and Phinehas, served as the Lord’s priests.)
speaker: Narrator

text:
The day came, and Elkanah sacrificed.
(Now he used to give meat portions to his wife Peninnah and to all her sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: But to Hannah he would give a double portion because he loved Hannah, although the Lord had not enabled her to have children.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her rival used to aggravate her to the point of exasperation, just to irritate her, since the Lord had not enabled her to have children.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is how it would go year after year. As often as she went up to the Lord’s house, Peninnah would offend her in that way.)
So she cried and refused to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then her husband Elkanah said to her, “Hannah, why are you crying and why won’t you eat? Why are you so upset? Am I not better to you than ten sons?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Hannah got up after they had finished eating and drinking in Shiloh.
At the time Eli the priest was sitting in his chair by the doorpost of the Lord’s sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for Hannah, she was very distressed. She prayed to the Lord and was, in fact, weeping.
speaker: Narrator

text: She made a vow saying, “O Lord of Heaven’s Armies, if you would truly look on the suffering of your servant, and would keep me in mind and not neglect your servant, and give your servant a male child, then I will dedicate him to the Lord all the days of his life. His hair will never be cut.”
speaker: Narrator

text: It turned out that she did a great deal of praying before the Lord. Meanwhile Eli was watching her mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for Hannah, she was speaking in her mind. Only her lips were moving; her voice could not be heard. So Eli thought she was a drunkard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to her, “How much longer do you intend to get drunk? Put away your wine!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Hannah replied, “Not so, my lord! I am a woman under a great deal of stress. I haven’t drunk wine or beer. But I have poured out my soul before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t consider your servant a wicked woman. It’s just that, to this point, I have spoken from my deep pain and anguish.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Eli replied, “Go in peace, and may the God of Israel grant the request that you have asked of him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She said, “May I, your servant, find favor in your sight.” So the woman went her way and got something to eat. Her face no longer looked sad.
speaker: Narrator

text: They got up early the next morning. Then they worshiped the Lord and returned to their home at Ramathaim. Elkanah was intimate with his wife Hannah, and the Lord called her to mind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Hannah became pregnant.
In the course of time she gave birth to a son. And she named him Samuel, thinking, “I asked the Lord for him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man Elkanah and all his family went up to make the yearly sacrifice to the Lord and to keep his vow.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Hannah did not go up with them, because she had told her husband, “Not until the boy is weaned. Then I will bring him so that he may appear before the Lord. And he will remain there from then on.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then her husband Elkanah said to her, “Do what you think best. Stay until you have weaned him. Only may the Lord fulfill his promise.”
So the woman stayed and nursed her son until she had weaned him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she took him up with her as soon as she had weaned him, along with three bulls, an ephah of flour, and a container of wine. She came to the Lord’s house at Shiloh, and the boy was with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They slaughtered the bull, then brought the boy to Eli.
speaker: Narrator

text: She said, “My lord. Just as surely as you are alive, my lord, I am the woman who previously stood here with you in order to pray to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this boy I prayed, and the Lord has given me the request that I asked of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I also dedicate him to the Lord. For all the days of his life he is dedicated to the Lord.” Then he bowed down there in worship to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hannah prayed,
“My heart has rejoiced in the Lord;
my horn has been raised high because of the Lord.
I have loudly denounced my enemies.
Indeed I rejoice in your deliverance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No one is holy like the Lord!
There is no one other than you!
There is no rock like our God!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t keep speaking so arrogantly.
Proud talk should not come out of your mouth,
for the Lord is a God who knows;
he evaluates what people do.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The bows of warriors are shattered,
but those who stumbled have taken on strength.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The well fed hire themselves out to earn food,
but the hungry no longer lack.
Even the barren woman has given birth to seven,
but the one with many children has declined.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord both kills and gives life;
he brings down to the grave and raises up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord impoverishes and makes wealthy;
he humbles and he exalts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He lifts the weak from the dust;
he raises the poor from the ash heap
to seat them with princes—
he bestows on them an honored position.
The foundations of the earth belong to the Lord—
he placed the world on them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He watches over his holy ones,
but the wicked are made speechless in the darkness,
for it is not by one’s own strength that one prevails.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord shatters his adversaries;
he thunders against them from the heavens.
The Lord executes judgment to the ends of the earth.
He will strengthen his king
and exalt the power of his anointed one.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Elkanah went back home to Ramah.
The boy Samuel was serving the Lord with the favor of Eli the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the sons of Eli were wicked men. They did not acknowledge the Lord’s authority.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the priests’ routine with the people. Whenever anyone was making a sacrifice, the priest’s attendant would come with a three-pronged fork in his hand, just as the meat was boiling.
speaker: Narrator

text: He would jab it into the basin, kettle, cauldron, or pot. Everything that the fork would bring up the priest would take for himself. This is how they used to treat all the Israelites who came there to Shiloh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, before they burned the fat the priest’s attendant would come and say to the person who was making the sacrifice, “Give some meat for the priest to roast! He won’t accept boiled meat from you, but only raw.”
speaker: Narrator

text: If the individual said to him, “They should certainly burn the fat away first, then take for yourself whatever you wish,” then he would say, “No! Give it now! If not, I’ll take it by force!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The sin of these young men was very great in the Lord’s sight, for they treated the Lord’s offering with contempt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Samuel was ministering with the favor of the Lord. The boy was dressed in a linen ephod.
speaker: Narrator

text: His mother used to make him a small robe and bring it to him from time to time when she would go up with her husband to make the annual sacrifice.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eli would bless Elkanah and his wife saying, “May the Lord establish descendants for you from this woman in place of the one that she dedicated to the Lord.” Then they would go to their home.
speaker: Narrator

text: And indeed the Lord attended to Hannah. She got pregnant and gave birth to three sons and two daughters. But the boy Samuel grew up before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eli was very old. And he would hear about everything that his sons used to do to all the people of Israel and how they used to go to bed with the women who were stationed at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he said to them, “Why do you do these things, these evil things that I hear about from all these people?
speaker: Narrator

text: No, my sons! For the report that I hear circulating among the Lord’s people is not good.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man sins against a man, one may appeal to God on his behalf. But if a man sins against the Lord, who can intercede for him?” But Eli’s sons would not listen to their father. Indeed the Lord had decided to kill them.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, the boy Samuel was growing up and finding favor both with the Lord and with people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a man of God came to Eli and said to him, “This is what the Lord has said: ‘I plainly revealed myself to your ancestor’s house when they were slaves to the house of Pharaoh in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: I chose your ancestor from all the tribes of Israel to be my priest, to offer sacrifice on my altar, to burn incense, and to bear the ephod before me. I gave to your ancestor’s house all the fire offerings made by the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why are you scorning my sacrifice and my offering that I commanded for my dwelling place? You have honored your sons more than you have me by having made yourselves fat from the best parts of all the offerings of my people Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore the Lord, the God of Israel, says, ‘I really did say that your house and your ancestor’s house would serve me forever.’ But now the Lord says, ‘May it never be! For I will honor those who honor me, but those who despise me will be cursed!
speaker: Narrator

text: In fact, days are coming when I will remove your strength and the strength of your father’s house. There will not be an old man in your house!
speaker: Narrator

text: You will see trouble in my dwelling place! Israel will experience blessings, but there will not be an old man in your house for all time.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any man of yours that I do not cut off from my altar, I will cause his eyes to fail and will cause him grief. All those born to your family will die by the sword of man.
speaker: Narrator

text: This will be a confirming sign for you that will be fulfilled through your two sons, Hophni and Phinehas: in a single day they both will die!
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I will raise up for myself a faithful priest. He will do what is in my heart and soul. I will build for him a lasting dynasty, and he will serve my chosen one for all time.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone who remains in your house will come to bow before him for a little money and for a scrap of bread. Each will say, “Assign me to a priestly task so I can eat a scrap of bread.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the boy Samuel continued serving the Lord under Eli’s supervision. Receiving a message from the Lord was rare in those days; revelatory visions were infrequent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eli’s eyes had begun to fail, so that he was unable to see well. At that time he was lying down in his place,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the lamp of God had not yet been extinguished. Samuel was lying down in the temple of the Lord as well; the ark of God was also there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord called to Samuel, and he replied, “Here I am!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he ran to Eli and said, “Here I am, for you called me.” But Eli said, “I didn’t call you. Go back and lie down.” So he went back and lay down.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord again called, “Samuel!” So Samuel got up and went to Eli and said, “Here I am, for you called me.” But Eli said, “I didn’t call you, my son. Go back and lie down.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Samuel did not yet know the Lord; the Lord’s messages had not yet been revealed to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord called Samuel a third time. So he got up and went to Eli and said, “Here I am, for you called me!” Eli then realized that it was the Lord who was calling the boy.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Eli said to Samuel, “Go back and lie down. When he calls you, say, ‘Speak, Lord, for your servant is listening.’ So Samuel went back and lay down in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord came and stood nearby, calling as he had previously done, “Samuel! Samuel!” Samuel replied, “Speak, for your servant is listening!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Samuel, “Look! I am about to do something in Israel; when anyone hears about it, both of his ears will tingle.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day I will carry out against Eli everything that I spoke about his house—from start to finish!
speaker: Narrator

text: You should tell him that I am about to judge his house forever because of the sin that he knew about. For his sons were cursing God, and he did not rebuke them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore I swore an oath to the house of Eli, ‘The sin of the house of Eli can never be forgiven by sacrifice or by grain offering.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Samuel lay down until morning. Then he opened the doors of the Lord’s house. But Samuel was afraid to tell Eli about the vision.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, Eli called Samuel and said, “Samuel, my son!” He replied, “Here I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Eli said, “What message did he speak to you? Don’t conceal it from me. God will judge you severely if you conceal from me anything that he said to you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Samuel told him everything. He did not hold back anything from him. Eli said, “The Lord will do what he pleases.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel continued to grow, and the Lord was with him. None of his prophecies fell to the ground unfulfilled.
speaker: Narrator

text: All Israel from Dan to Beer Sheba realized that Samuel was confirmed as a prophet of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord again appeared in Shiloh, for it was in Shiloh that the Lord had revealed himself to Samuel through a message from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Samuel revealed the word of the Lord to all Israel.
Then the Israelites went out to fight the Philistines. They camped at Ebenezer, and the Philistines camped at Aphek.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines arranged their forces to fight Israel. As the battle spread out, Israel was defeated by the Philistines, who killed about 4,000 men in the battle line in the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the army came back to the camp, the elders of Israel said, “Why did the Lord let us be defeated today by the Philistines? Let’s take with us the ark of the covenant of the Lord from Shiloh. When it is with us, it will save us from the hand of our enemies.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the army sent to Shiloh, and they took from there the ark of the covenant of the Lord of Heaven’s Armies, who sits between the cherubim. Now the two sons of Eli, Hophni and Phinehas, were there with the ark of the covenant of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the ark of the covenant of the Lord arrived at the camp, all Israel shouted so loudly that the ground shook.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Philistines heard the sound of the shout, they said, “What is this loud shout in the camp of the Hebrews?” Then they realized that the ark of the Lord had arrived at the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines were scared because they thought that gods had come to the camp. They said, “Woe to us! We’ve never seen anything like this!
speaker: Narrator

text: Woe to us! Who can deliver us from the hand of these mighty gods? These are the gods who struck the Egyptians with all sorts of plagues in the desert!
speaker: Narrator

text: Be strong and act like men, you Philistines, or else you will wind up serving the Hebrews the way they have served you! Act like men and fight!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Philistines fought. Israel was defeated; they all ran home. The slaughter was very great; 30,000 foot soldiers from Israel fell in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: The ark of God was taken, and the two sons of Eli, Hophni and Phinehas, were killed.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day a Benjaminite ran from the battle lines and came to Shiloh. His clothes were torn, and dirt was on his head.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he arrived in Shiloh, Eli was sitting in his chair on the lookout by the side of the road, for he was very worried about the ark of God. As the man entered the city to give his report, the whole city cried out.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Eli heard the outcry, he said, “What’s this commotion?” The man quickly came and told Eli.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Eli was ninety-eight years old and his eyes looked straight ahead; he was unable to see.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man said to Eli, “I am the one who came from the battle lines! Just today I fled from the battle lines!” Eli asked, “How did things go, my son?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The messenger replied, “Israel has fled from the Philistines! The army has suffered a great defeat! Your two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, are dead! The ark of God has been captured!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he mentioned the ark of God, Eli fell backward from his chair beside the gate. He broke his neck and died, for he was old and heavy. He had judged Israel for forty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: His daughter-in-law, the wife of Phinehas, was pregnant and close to giving birth. When she heard that the ark of God was captured and that her father-in-law and her husband were dead, she doubled over and gave birth. But her labor pains were too much for her.
speaker: Narrator

text: As she was dying, the women who were there with her said, “Don’t be afraid! You have given birth to a son!” But she did not reply or pay any attention.
speaker: Narrator

text: She named the boy Ichabod, saying, “The glory has departed from Israel,” referring to the capture of the ark of God and the deaths of her father-in-law and her husband.
speaker: Narrator

text: She said, “The glory has departed from Israel, because the ark of God has been captured.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Philistines had captured the ark of God and brought it from Ebenezer to Ashdod.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines took the ark of God and brought it into the temple of Dagon, where they positioned it beside Dagon.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the residents of Ashdod got up early the next day, Dagon was lying on the ground before the ark of the Lord. So they took Dagon and set him back in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when they got up early the following day, Dagon was again lying on the ground before the ark of the Lord. The head of Dagon and his two hands were sheared off and were lying at the threshold. Only Dagon’s body was left intact.
speaker: Narrator

text: (For this reason, to this very day, neither Dagon’s priests nor anyone else who enters Dagon’s temple steps on Dagon’s threshold in Ashdod.)
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord attacked the residents of Ashdod severely, bringing devastation on them. He struck the people of both Ashdod and the surrounding area with sores.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the people of Ashdod saw what was happening, they said, “The ark of the God of Israel should not remain with us, for he has attacked both us and our god Dagon!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they assembled all the leaders of the Philistines and asked, “What should we do with the ark of the God of Israel?” They replied, “The ark of the God of Israel should be moved to Gath.” So they moved the ark of the God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: But after it had been moved the Lord attacked that city as well, causing a great deal of panic. He struck all the people of that city with sores.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So they sent the ark of God to Ekron.
But when the ark of God arrived at Ekron, the residents of Ekron cried out saying, “They have brought the ark of the God of Israel here to kill our people!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they assembled all the leaders of the Philistines and said, “Get the ark of the God of Israel out of here! Let it go back to its own place so that it won’t kill us and our people!” The terror of death was throughout the entire city; God was attacking them very severely there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people who did not die were struck with sores; the city’s cry for help went all the way up to heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the ark of the Lord had been in the land of the Philistines for seven months,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Philistines called the priests and the omen readers, saying, “What should we do with the ark of the Lord? Advise us as to how we should send it back to its place.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They replied, “If you are going to send the ark of the God of Israel back, don’t send it away empty. Be sure to return it with a guilt offering. Then you will be healed, and you will understand why his hand has not been removed from you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
They inquired, “What is the guilt offering that we should send to him?”
They replied, “The Philistine leaders number five. So send five gold sores and five gold mice, for it is the same plague that has afflicted both you and your leaders.
speaker: Narrator

text: You should make images of the sores and images of the mice that are destroying the land. You should honor the God of Israel. Perhaps he will release his grip on you, your gods, and your land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why harden your hearts like the Egyptians and Pharaoh did? When God treated them harshly, didn’t the Egyptians send the Israelites on their way?
speaker: Narrator

text: So now go and make a new cart. Get two cows that have calves and that have never had a yoke placed on them. Harness the cows to the cart, and take their calves from them back to their stalls.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then take the ark of the Lord and place it on the cart, and put in a chest beside it the gold objects you are sending to him as a guilt offering. You should then send it on its way.
speaker: Narrator

text: But keep an eye on it. If it should go up by the way of its own border to Beth Shemesh, then he has brought this great calamity on us. But if that is not the case, then we will know that it was not his hand that struck us; rather, it just happened to us by accident.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the men did as instructed. They took two cows that had calves and harnessed the cows to a cart; they also removed their calves to their stalls.
speaker: Narrator

text: They put the ark of the Lord on the cart, along with the chest, the gold mice, and the images of the sores.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the cows went directly on the road to Beth Shemesh. They went along that route, bellowing more and more; they turned neither to the right nor to the left. The leaders of the Philistines were walking along behind them all the way to the border of Beth Shemesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the residents of Beth Shemesh were harvesting wheat in the valley. When they looked up and saw the ark, they were pleased at the sight.
speaker: Narrator

text: The cart was coming to the field of Joshua, who was from Beth Shemesh. It paused there near a big stone. Then they cut up the wood of the cart and offered the cows as a burnt offering to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levites took down the ark of the Lord and the chest that was with it, which contained the gold objects. They placed them near the big stone. At that time the people of Beth Shemesh offered burnt offerings and made sacrifices to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The five leaders of the Philistines watched what was happening and then returned to Ekron on the same day.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the gold sores that the Philistines brought as a guilt offering to the Lord—one for each of the following cities: Ashdod, Gaza, Ashkelon, Gath, and Ekron.
speaker: Narrator

text: The gold mice corresponded in number to all the Philistine cities of the five leaders, from the fortified cities to hamlet villages, to greater Abel. They positioned the ark of the Lord on a rock until this very day in the field of Joshua who was from Beth Shemesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord struck down some of the people of Beth Shemesh because they had looked into the ark of the Lord; he struck down 50,070 of the men. The people grieved because the Lord had struck the people with a hard blow.
speaker: Narrator

text: The residents of Beth Shemesh asked, “Who is able to stand before the Lord, this holy God? To whom will the ark go up from here?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they sent messengers to the residents of Kiriath Jearim, saying, “The Philistines have returned the ark of the Lord. Come down here and take it back home with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the people of Kiriath Jearim came and took the ark of the Lord; they brought it to the house of Abinadab located on the hill. They consecrated Eleazar his son to guard the ark of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was quite a long time—some twenty years in all—that the ark stayed at Kiriath Jearim. All the people of Israel longed for the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said to all the people of Israel, “If you are really turning to the Lord with all your hearts, remove from among you the foreign gods and the images of Ashtoreth. Give your hearts to the Lord and serve only him. Then he will deliver you from the hand of the Philistines.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Israelites removed the Baals and images of Ashtoreth. They served only the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel said, “Gather all Israel to Mizpah, and I will pray to the Lord on your behalf.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After they had assembled at Mizpah, they drew water and poured it out before the Lord. They fasted on that day, and they confessed there, “We have sinned against the Lord.” So Samuel led the people of Israel at Mizpah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Philistines heard that the Israelites had gathered at Mizpah, the leaders of the Philistines went up against Israel. When the Israelites heard about this, they were afraid of the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites said to Samuel, “Keep crying out to the Lord our God so that he may save us from the hand of the Philistines!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Samuel took a nursing lamb and offered it as a whole burnt offering to the Lord. Samuel cried out to the Lord on Israel’s behalf, and the Lord answered him.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Samuel was offering burnt offerings, the Philistines approached to do battle with Israel. But on that day the Lord thundered loudly against the Philistines. He caused them to panic, and they were defeated by Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the men of Israel left Mizpah and chased the Philistines, striking them down all the way to an area below Beth Car.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel took a stone and placed it between Mizpah and Shen. He named it Ebenezer, saying, “Up to here the Lord has helped us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Philistines were defeated; they did not invade Israel again. The hand of the Lord was against the Philistines all the days of Samuel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The cities that the Philistines had captured from Israel were returned to Israel, from Ekron to Gath. Israel also delivered their territory from the control of the Philistines. There was also peace between Israel and the Amorites.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Samuel led Israel all the days of his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Year after year he used to travel the circuit of Bethel, Gilgal, and Mizpah; he used to judge Israel in all these places.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he would return to Ramah, because his home was there. He also judged Israel there and built an altar to the Lord there.
speaker: Narrator

text: In his old age Samuel appointed his sons as judges over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of his firstborn son was Joel, and the name of his second son was Abijah. They were judges in Beer Sheba.
speaker: Narrator

text: But his sons did not follow his ways. Instead, they made money dishonestly, accepted bribes, and perverted justice.
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the elders of Israel gathered together and approached Samuel at Ramah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to him, “Look, you are old, and your sons don’t follow your ways. So now appoint over us a king to lead us, just like all the other nations have.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But this request displeased Samuel, for they said, “Give us a king to lead us.” So Samuel prayed to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Samuel, “Do everything the people request of you. For it is not you that they have rejected, but it is me that they have rejected as their king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as they have done from the day that I brought them up from Egypt until this very day, they have rejected me and have served other gods. This is what they are also doing to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So now do as they say. But you must warn them and make them aware of the policies of the king who will rule over them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Samuel spoke all the Lord’s words to the people who were asking him for a king.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Here are the policies of the king who will rule over you: He will conscript your sons and put them in his chariot forces and in his cavalry; they will run in front of his chariot.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will appoint for himself leaders of thousands and leaders of fifties, as well as those who plow his ground, reap his harvest, and make his weapons of war and his chariot equipment.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will take your daughters to be ointment makers, cooks, and bakers.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will take your best fields, vineyards, and olive groves, and give them to his own servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will demand a tenth of your seed and of the produce of your vineyards and give it to his administrators and his servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will take your male and female servants, as well as your best cattle and your donkeys, and assign them for his own use.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will demand a tenth of your flocks, and you yourselves will be his servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day you will cry out because of your king whom you have chosen for yourselves, but the Lord won’t answer you in that day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people refused to heed Samuel’s warning. Instead they said, “No! There will be a king over us!
speaker: Narrator

text: We will be like all the other nations. Our king will judge us and lead us and fight our battles.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Samuel listened to everything the people said and then reported it to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Samuel, “Do as they say and install a king over them.” Then Samuel said to the men of Israel, “Each of you go back to his own city.”
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a Benjaminite man named Kish son of Abiel, the son of Zeror, the son of Becorath, the son of Aphiah of Benjamin. Kish was a prominent person.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had a son named Saul, a handsome young man. There was no one among the Israelites more handsome than he was; he stood head and shoulders above all the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: The donkeys of Saul’s father Kish wandered off, so Kish said to his son Saul, “Take one of the servants with you and go look for the donkeys.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul crossed through the hill country of Ephraim, passing through the land of Shalisha, but they did not find them. So they crossed through the land of Shaalim, but they were not there. Then he crossed through the land of Benjamin, and still they did not find them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came to the land of Zuph, Saul said to his servant who was with him, “Come on, let’s head back before my father quits worrying about the donkeys and becomes anxious about us!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the servant said to him, “Look, there is a man of God in this town. He is highly respected. Everything that he says really happens. Now let’s go there. Perhaps he will tell us where we should go from here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul said to his servant, “All right, we can go. But what can we bring the man, since the food in our bags is used up? We have no gift to take to the man of God. What do we have?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The servant went on to answer Saul, “Look, I happen to have in my hand a quarter shekel of silver. I will give it to the man of God and he will tell us where we should go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: (Now it used to be in Israel that whenever someone went to inquire of God he would say, “Come on, let’s go to the seer.” For today’s prophet used to be called a seer.)
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul said to his servant, “That’s a good idea! Come on. Let’s go.” So they went to the town where the man of God was.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they were going up the ascent to the town, they met some girls coming out to draw water. They said to them, “Is this where the seer is?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They replied, “Yes, straight ahead! But hurry now, for he came to the town today, and the people are making a sacrifice at the high place.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you enter the town, you can find him before he goes up to the high place to eat. The people won’t eat until he arrives, for he must bless the sacrifice. Once that happens, those who have been invited will eat. Now go on up, for this is the time when you can find him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they went up to the town. As they were heading for the middle of the town, Samuel was coming in their direction to go up to the high place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the day before Saul arrived, the Lord had told Samuel:
speaker: Narrator

text: “At this time tomorrow I will send to you a man from the land of Benjamin. You must consecrate him as a leader over my people Israel. He will save my people from the hand of the Philistines. For I have looked with favor on my people. Their cry has reached me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Samuel saw Saul, the Lord said, “Here is the man that I told you about. He will rule over my people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As Saul approached Samuel in the middle of the gate, he said, “Please tell me where the seer’s house is.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel replied to Saul, “I am the seer! Go up in front of me to the high place! Today you will eat with me and in the morning I will send you away. I will tell you everything that you are thinking.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t be concerned about the donkeys that you lost three days ago, for they have been found. Whom does all Israel desire? Is it not you, and all your father’s family?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul replied, “Am I not a Benjaminite, from the smallest of Israel’s tribes, and is not my family clan the smallest of all the clans in the tribe of Benjamin? Why do you speak to me in this way?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel brought Saul and his servant into the room and gave them a place at the head of those who had been invited. There were about thirty people present.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said to the cook, “Give me the portion of meat that I gave to you—the one I asked you to keep with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the cook picked up the leg and brought it and set it in front of Saul. Samuel said, “What was kept is now set before you! Eat, for it has been kept for you for this meeting time, from the time I said, ‘I have invited the people.’” So Saul ate with Samuel that day.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came down from the high place to the town, Samuel spoke with Saul on the roof.
speaker: Narrator

text: They got up at dawn and Samuel called to Saul on the roof, “Get up, so I can send you on your way.” So Saul got up and the two of them—he and Samuel—went outside.
speaker: Narrator

text: While they were going down to the edge of town, Samuel said to Saul, “Tell the servant to go on ahead of us.” So he did. Samuel then said, “You remain here awhile, so I can inform you of God’s message.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel took a small container of olive oil and poured it on Saul’s head. Samuel kissed him and said, “The Lord has chosen you to lead his people Israel! You will rule over the Lord’s people and you will deliver them from the power of the enemies who surround them. This will be your sign that the Lord has chosen you as leader over his inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you leave me today, you will find two men near Rachel’s tomb at Zelzah on Benjamin’s border. They will say to you, ‘The donkeys you have gone looking for have been found. Your father is no longer concerned about the donkeys but has become anxious about you two! He is asking, “What should I do about my son?”’
speaker: Narrator

text: “As you continue on from there, you will come to the tall tree of Tabor. At that point three men who are going up to God at Bethel will meet you. One of them will be carrying three young goats, one of them will be carrying three round loaves of bread, and one of them will be carrying a container of wine.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will ask you how you’re doing and will give you two loaves of bread. You will accept them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterward you will go to Gibeah of God, where there are Philistine officials. When you enter the town, you will meet a company of prophets coming down from the high place. They will have harps, tambourines, flutes, and lyres, and they will be prophesying.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Spirit of the Lord will rush upon you and you will prophesy with them. You will be changed into a different person.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When these signs have taken place, do whatever your hand finds to do, for God will be with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will go down to Gilgal before me. I am going to join you there to offer burnt offerings and to make peace offerings. You should wait for seven days until I arrive and tell you what to do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As Saul turned to leave Samuel, God changed his inmost person. All these signs happened on that very day.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul and his servant arrived at Gibeah, a company of prophets was coming out to meet him. Then the Spirit of God rushed upon Saul and he prophesied among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When everyone who had known him previously saw him prophesying with the prophets, the people asked one another, “What on earth has happened to the son of Kish? Does even Saul belong with the prophets?”
speaker: Narrator

text: A man who was from there replied, “And who is their father?” Therefore this became a proverb: “Is even Saul among the prophets?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul had finished prophesying, he went to the high place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul’s uncle asked him and his servant, “Where did you go?” Saul replied, “To look for the donkeys. But when we realized they were lost, we went to Samuel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul’s uncle said, “Tell me what Samuel said to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said to his uncle, “He assured us that the donkeys had been found.” But Saul did not tell him what Samuel had said about the matter of kingship.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel called the people together before the Lord at Mizpah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to the Israelites, “This is what the Lord God of Israel has said, ‘I brought Israel up from Egypt and I delivered you from the power of the Egyptians and from the power of all the kingdoms that oppressed you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But today you have rejected your God who saves you from all your trouble and distress. You have said, “No! Appoint a king over us.” Now take your positions before the Lord by your tribes and by your clans.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel brought all the tribes of Israel near, and the tribe of Benjamin was chosen by lot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he brought the tribe of Benjamin near by its families, and the family of Matri was chosen by lot. At last Saul son of Kish was chosen by lot. But when they looked for him, he was nowhere to be found.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they inquired again of the Lord, “Has the man arrived here yet?” The Lord said, “He has hidden himself among the equipment.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they ran and brought him from there. When he took his position among the people, he stood head and shoulders above them all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel said to all the people, “Do you see the one whom the Lord has chosen? Indeed, there is no one like him among all the people.” All the people shouted out, “Long live the king!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel talked to the people about how the kingship would work. He wrote it all down on a scroll and set it before the Lord. Then Samuel sent all the people away to their homes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even Saul went to his home in Gibeah. With him went some brave men whose hearts God had touched.
speaker: Narrator

text: But some wicked men said, “How can this man save us?” They despised him and did not even bring him a gift. But Saul said nothing about it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nahash the Ammonite marched against Jabesh Gilead. All the men of Jabesh Gilead said to Nahash, “Make a treaty with us and we will serve you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Nahash the Ammonite said to them, “The only way I will make a treaty with you is if you let me gouge out the right eye of every one of you and in so doing humiliate all Israel!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The elders of Jabesh said to him, “Leave us alone for seven days so that we can send messengers throughout the territory of Israel. If there is no one who can deliver us, we will come out voluntarily to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the messengers went to Gibeah (where Saul lived) and informed the people of these matters, all the people wept loudly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Saul was walking behind the oxen as he came from the field. Saul asked, “What has happened to the people? Why are they weeping?” So they told him about the men of Jabesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Spirit of God rushed upon Saul when he heard these words, and he became very angry.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took a pair of oxen and cut them up. Then he sent the pieces throughout the territory of Israel by the hand of messengers, who said, “Whoever does not go out after Saul and after Samuel should expect this to be done to his oxen!” Then the terror of the Lord fell on the people, and they went out as one army.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul counted them at Bezek, the Israelites were 300,000 strong and the men of Judah numbered 30,000.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to the messengers who had come, “Here’s what you should say to the men of Jabesh Gilead: ‘Tomorrow deliverance will come to you when the sun is fully up.’” When the messengers went and told the men of Jabesh Gilead, they were happy.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Jabesh said, “Tomorrow we will come out to you and you can do with us whatever you wish.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day Saul placed the people in three groups. They went to the Ammonite camp during the morning watch and struck them down until the hottest part of the day. The survivors scattered; no two of them remained together.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the people said to Samuel, “Who were the ones asking, ‘Will Saul reign over us?’ Hand over those men so we may execute them!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Saul said, “No one will be killed on this day. For today the Lord has given Israel a victory!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said to the people, “Come on! Let’s go to Gilgal and renew the kingship there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the people went to Gilgal, where they established Saul as king in the Lord’s presence. They offered up peace offerings there in the Lord’s presence. Saul and all the Israelites were very happy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said to all Israel, “I have done everything you requested. I have given you a king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now look! This king walks before you. As for me, I am old and gray, and my sons are here with you. I have walked before you from the time of my youth till the present day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here I am. Bring a charge against me before the Lord and before his chosen king. Whose ox have I taken? Whose donkey have I taken? Whom have I wronged? Whom have I oppressed? From whose hand have I taken a bribe so that I would overlook something? Tell me, and I will return it to you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: They replied, “You have not wronged us or oppressed us. You have not taken anything from the hand of anyone.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “The Lord is witness against you, and his chosen king is witness this day, that you have not found any reason to accuse me.” They said, “He is witness!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said to the people, “The Lord is the one who chose Moses and Aaron and who brought your ancestors up from the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now take your positions, so I may confront you before the Lord regarding all the Lord’s just actions toward you and your ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jacob entered Egypt, your ancestors cried out to the Lord. The Lord sent Moses and Aaron, and they led your ancestors out of Egypt and settled them in this place.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But they forgot the Lord their God, so he gave them into the hand of Sisera, the general in command of Hazor’s army, and into the hands of the Philistines and the king of Moab, and they fought against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they cried out to the Lord and admitted, ‘We have sinned, for we have forsaken the Lord and have served the Baals and the images of Ashtoreth. Now deliver us from the hands of our enemies so that we may serve you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord sent Jerub Baal, Barak, Jephthah, and Samuel, and he delivered you from the hands of the enemies all around you, and you were able to live securely.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you saw that King Nahash of the Ammonites was advancing against you, you said to me, ‘No! A king will rule over us’—even though the Lord your God is your king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now look! Here is the king you have chosen—the one that you asked for! Look, the Lord has given you a king.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you fear the Lord, serving him and obeying him and not rebelling against what he says, and if both you and the king who rules over you follow the Lord your God, all will be well.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you don’t obey the Lord and rebel against what the Lord says, the hand of the Lord will be against both you and your king.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So now, take your positions and watch this great thing that the Lord is about to do in your sight.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is this not the time of the wheat harvest? I will call on the Lord so that he makes it thunder and rain. Realize and see what a great sin you have committed before the Lord by asking for a king for yourselves.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Samuel called to the Lord, and the Lord made it thunder and rain that day. All the people were very afraid of both the Lord and Samuel.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people said to Samuel, “Pray to the Lord your God on behalf of us—your servants—so we won’t die, for we have added to all our sins by asking for a king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel said to the people, “Don’t be afraid. You have indeed sinned. However, don’t turn aside from the Lord. Serve the Lord with all your heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: You should not turn aside after empty things that can’t profit and can’t deliver, since they are empty.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will not abandon his people because he wants to uphold his great reputation. The Lord was pleased to make you his own people.
speaker: Narrator

text: As far as I am concerned, far be it from me to sin against the Lord by ceasing to pray for you! I will instruct you in the way that is good and upright.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, fear the Lord and serve him faithfully with all your heart. Just look at the great things he has done for you!
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you continue to do evil, both you and your king will be swept away.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul was [thirty] years old when he began to reign; he ruled over Israel for [forty] years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul selected for himself 3,000 men from Israel. Of these 2,000 were with Saul at Micmash and in the hill country of Bethel; the remaining 1,000 were with Jonathan at Gibeah in the territory of Benjamin. He sent all the rest of the people back home.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan attacked the Philistine outpost that was at Geba and the Philistines heard about it. Then Saul alerted all the land saying, “Let the Hebrews pay attention!”
speaker: Narrator

text: All Israel heard this message, “Saul has attacked the Philistine outpost, and now Israel is repulsive to the Philistines!” So the people were summoned to join Saul at Gilgal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile the Philistines gathered to battle with Israel. Then they went up against Israel with 3,000 chariots, 6,000 horsemen, and an army as numerous as the sand on the seashore. They went up and camped at Micmash, east of Beth Aven.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Israel realized they had a problem because their army was hard pressed. So the army hid in caves, thickets, cliffs, strongholds, and cisterns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the Hebrews crossed over the Jordan River to the land of Gad and Gilead. But Saul stayed at Gilgal; the entire army that was with him was terrified.
speaker: Narrator

text: He waited for seven days, the time period indicated by Samuel. But Samuel did not come to Gilgal, and the army began to abandon Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul said, “Bring me the burnt offering and the peace offerings.” Then he offered a burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just when he had finished offering the burnt offering, Samuel appeared on the scene. Saul went out to meet him and to greet him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Samuel said, “What have you done?” Saul replied, “When I saw that the army had started to abandon me, and that you didn’t come at the appointed time, and that the Philistines had assembled at Micmash,
speaker: Narrator

text: I thought, ‘Now the Philistines will come down on me at Gilgal and I have not sought the Lord’s favor.’ So I felt obligated to offer the burnt offering.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel said to Saul, “You have made a foolish choice! You have not obeyed the commandment that the Lord your God gave you. Had you done that, the Lord would have established your kingdom over Israel forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now your kingdom will not continue. The Lord has sought out for himself a man who is loyal to him, and the Lord has appointed him to be leader over his people, for you have not obeyed what the Lord commanded you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel set out and went up from Gilgal to Gibeah in the territory of Benjamin. Saul mustered the army that remained with him; there were about 600 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul, his son Jonathan, and the army that remained with them stayed in Gibeah in the territory of Benjamin, while the Philistines camped in Micmash.
speaker: Narrator

text: Raiding bands went out from the camp of the Philistines in three groups. One band turned toward the road leading to Ophrah by the land of Shual;
speaker: Narrator

text: another band turned toward the road leading to Beth Horon; and yet another band turned toward the road leading to the border that overlooks the valley of Zeboyim in the direction of the desert.
speaker: Narrator

text: A blacksmith could not be found in all the land of Israel, for the Philistines had said, “This will prevent the Hebrews from making swords and spears.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So all Israel had to go down to the Philistines in order to get their plowshares, cutting instruments, axes, and sickles sharpened.
speaker: Narrator

text: They charged two-thirds of a shekel to sharpen plowshares and cutting instruments, and one-third of a shekel to sharpen picks and axes, and to set ox goads.
speaker: Narrator

text: So on the day of the battle no sword or spear was to be found in the hand of anyone in the army that was with Saul and Jonathan. No one but Saul and his son Jonathan had them.
speaker: Narrator

text: A garrison of the Philistines had gone out to the pass at Micmash.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then one day Jonathan son of Saul said to his armor-bearer, “Come on, let’s go over to the Philistine garrison that is opposite us.” But he did not let his father know.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Saul was sitting under a pomegranate tree in Migron, on the outskirts of Gibeah. The army that was with him numbered about 600 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Ahijah was carrying an ephod. He was the son of Ahitub, who was the brother of Ichabod and a son of Phinehas, son of Eli, the priest of the Lord in Shiloh. The army was unaware that Jonathan had left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there was a steep cliff on each side of the pass through which Jonathan intended to go to reach the Philistine garrison. One cliff was named Bozez, the other Seneh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The cliff to the north was closer to Micmash, the one to the south closer to Geba.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan said to his armor-bearer, “Come on, let’s go over to the garrison of these uncircumcised men. Perhaps the Lord will intervene for us. Nothing can prevent the Lord from delivering, whether by many or by a few.”
speaker: Narrator

text: His armor-bearer said to him, “Do everything that is on your mind. Do as you’re inclined. I’m with you all the way!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan replied, “All right. We’ll go over to these men and fight them.
speaker: Narrator

text: If they say to us, ‘Stay put until we approach you,’ we will stay right there and not go up to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if they say, ‘Come up against us,’ we will go up. For in that case the Lord has given them into our hand—it will be a sign to us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When they made themselves known to the Philistine garrison, the Philistines said, “Look! The Hebrews are coming out of the holes in which they hid themselves.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the men of the garrison said to Jonathan and his armor-bearer, “Come on up to us so we can teach you a thing or two!” Then Jonathan said to his armor-bearer, “Come up behind me, for the Lord has given them into the hand of Israel!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan crawled up on his hands and feet, with his armor-bearer following behind him. Jonathan struck down the Philistines, while his armor-bearer came along behind him and killed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: In this initial skirmish Jonathan and his armor-bearer struck down about twenty men in an area that measured half an acre.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then fear overwhelmed those who were in the camp, those who were in the field, all the army in the garrison, and the raiding bands. They trembled and the ground shook. This fear was caused by God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul’s watchmen at Gibeah in the territory of Benjamin looked on as the crowd of soldiers seemed to melt away first in one direction and then in another.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul said to the army that was with him, “Muster the troops and see who is no longer with us.” When they mustered the troops, Jonathan and his armor-bearer were not there.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul said to Ahijah, “Bring near the ephod,” for he was at that time wearing the ephod in front of the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Saul spoke to the priest, the panic in the Philistines’ camp was becoming greater and greater. So Saul said to the priest, “Withdraw your hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul and all the army assembled and marched into battle, where they found the Philistines in total panic killing one another with their swords.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Hebrews who had earlier gone over to the Philistine side joined the Israelites who were with Saul and Jonathan.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the Israelites who had hidden themselves in the hill country of Ephraim heard that the Philistines had fled, they too pursued them in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord delivered Israel that day, and the battle shifted over to Beth Aven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the men of Israel were hard pressed that day, for Saul had made the army agree to this oath: “Cursed be the man who eats food before evening. I will get my vengeance on my enemies!” So no one in the army ate anything.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the whole army entered the forest, and there was honey on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the army entered the forest, they saw the honey flowing, but no one ate any of it, for the army was afraid of the oath.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jonathan had not heard about the oath his father had made the army take. He extended the end of his staff that was in his hand and dipped it in the honeycomb. When he ate it, his eyes gleamed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then someone from the army informed him, “Your father put the army under a strict oath saying, ‘Cursed be the man who eats food today.’ That is why the army is tired.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jonathan said, “My father has caused trouble for the land. See how my eyes gleamed when I tasted just a little of this honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: Certainly if the army had eaten some of the enemies’ provisions that they came across today, would not the slaughter of the Philistines have been even greater?”
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day the army struck down the Philistines from Micmash to Aijalon, and they became very tired.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the army rushed greedily on the plunder, confiscating sheep, cattle, and calves. They slaughtered them right on the ground, and the army ate them, blood and all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now it was reported to Saul, “Look, the army is sinning against the Lord by eating even the blood.” He said, “All of you have broken the covenant! Roll a large stone over here to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul said, “Scatter out among the army and say to them, ‘Each of you bring to me your ox and sheep and slaughter them in this spot and eat. But don’t sin against the Lord by eating the blood.” So that night each one brought his ox and slaughtered it there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul built an altar for the Lord; it was the first time he had built an altar for the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said, “Let’s go down after the Philistines at night; we will rout them until the break of day. We won’t leave any of them alive!” They replied, “Do whatever seems best to you.” But the priest said, “Let’s approach God here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul asked God, “Should I go down after the Philistines? Will you deliver them into the hand of Israel?” But he did not answer him that day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul said, “All you leaders of the army come here. Find out how this sin occurred today.
speaker: Narrator

text: For as surely as the Lord, the deliverer of Israel, lives, even if it turns out to be my own son Jonathan, he will certainly die!” But no one from the army said anything.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to all Israel, “You will be on one side, and I and my son Jonathan will be on the other side.” The army replied to Saul, “Do whatever you think is best.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul said, “O Lord God of Israel! If this sin has been committed by me or by my son Jonathan, then, O Lord God of Israel, respond with Urim. But if this sin has been committed by your people Israel, respond with Thummim.” Then Jonathan and Saul were indicated by lot, while the army was exonerated.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul said, “Cast the lot between me and my son Jonathan!” Jonathan was indicated by lot.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul said to Jonathan, “Tell me what you have done.” Jonathan told him, “I used the end of the staff that was in my hand to taste a little honey. I must die!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said, “God will punish me severely if Jonathan doesn’t die!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the army said to Saul, “Should Jonathan, who won this great victory in Israel, die? May it never be! As surely as the Lord lives, not a single hair of his head will fall to the ground, for it is with the help of God that he has acted today.” So the army rescued Jonathan from death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul stopped chasing the Philistines, and the Philistines went back home.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Saul had secured his royal position over Israel, he fought against all their enemies on all sides—the Moabites, Ammonites, Edomites, the kings of Zobah, and the Philistines. In every direction that he turned, he was victorious.
speaker: Narrator

text: He fought bravely, striking down the Amalekites and delivering Israel from the hand of its enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Saul were Jonathan, Ishvi, and Malki-Shua. He had two daughters; the older one was named Merab and the younger Michal.
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of Saul’s wife was Ahinoam, the daughter of Ahimaaz. The name of the general in command of his army was Abner son of Ner, Saul’s uncle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Kish was the father of Saul, and Ner the father of Abner was the son of Abiel.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was fierce war with the Philistines all the days of Saul. So whenever Saul saw anyone who was a warrior or a brave individual, he would conscript him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel said to Saul, “I was the one the Lord sent to anoint you as king over his people Israel. Now listen to what the Lord says.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here is what the Lord of Heaven’s Armies has said: ‘I carefully observed how the Amalekites opposed Israel along the way when Israel came up from Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: So go now and strike down the Amalekites. Destroy everything they have. Don’t spare them. Put them to death—man, woman, child, infant, ox, sheep, camel, and donkey alike.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul assembled the army and mustered them at Telaim. There were 200,000 foot soldiers and 10,000 men of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul proceeded to the city of Amalek, where he set an ambush in the wadi.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said to the Kenites, “Go on and leave! Go down from among the Amalekites. Otherwise I will sweep you away with them. After all, you were kind to all the Israelites when they came up from Egypt.” So the Kenites withdrew from among the Amalekites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul struck down the Amalekites all the way from Havilah to Shur, which is next to Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: He captured King Agag of the Amalekites alive, but he executed all Agag’s people with the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, Saul and the army spared Agag, along with the best of the flock, the cattle, the fatlings, and the lambs, as well as everything else that was of value. They were not willing to slaughter them. But they did slaughter everything that was despised and worthless.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord’s message came to Samuel:
speaker: Narrator

text: “I regret that I have made Saul king, for he has turned away from me and has not done what I told him to do.” Samuel became angry and he cried out to the Lord all that night.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel got up early to meet Saul the next morning. But Samuel was informed, “Saul has gone to Carmel where he is setting up a monument for himself.” Then Samuel left and went down to Gilgal.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Samuel came to Saul, Saul said to him, “May the Lord bless you! I have fulfilled the Lord’s orders.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel replied, “If that is the case, then what is this sound of sheep in my ears and the sound of cattle that I hear?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said, “They were brought from the Amalekites; the army spared the best of the flocks and cattle to sacrifice to the Lord our God. But everything else we slaughtered.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel said to Saul, “Wait a minute! Let me tell you what the Lord said to me last night.” Saul said to him, “Tell me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said, “Is it not true that when you were insignificant in your own eyes, you became head of the tribes of Israel? The Lord chose you as king over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord sent you on a campaign saying, ‘Go and exterminate those sinful Amalekites! Fight against them until you have destroyed them.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Why haven’t you obeyed the Lord? Instead you have greedily rushed upon the plunder! You have done what is wrong in the Lord’s estimation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul said to Samuel, “But I have obeyed the Lord! I went on the campaign the Lord sent me on. I brought back King Agag of the Amalekites after exterminating the Amalekites.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the army took from the plunder some of the sheep and cattle—the best of what was to be slaughtered—to sacrifice to the Lord your God in Gilgal.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Samuel said,
“Does the Lord take pleasure in burnt offerings and sacrifices
as much as he does in obedience?
Certainly, obedience is better than sacrifice;
paying attention is better than the fat of rams.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For rebellion is like the sin of divination,
and presumption is like the evil of idolatry.
Because you have rejected the Lord’s orders,
he has rejected you from being king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul said to Samuel, “I have sinned, for I have disobeyed what the Lord commanded and your words as well. For I was afraid of the army, and I obeyed their voice.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now please forgive my sin. Go back with me so I can worship the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said to Saul, “I will not go back with you, for you have rejected the Lord’s orders, and the Lord has rejected you from being king over Israel!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Samuel turned to leave, Saul grabbed the edge of his robe and it tore.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said to him, “The Lord has torn the kingdom of Israel from you this day and has given it to one of your colleagues who is better than you!
speaker: Narrator

text: The Preeminent One of Israel does not go back on his word or change his mind, for he is not a human being who changes his mind.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul again replied, “I have sinned. But please honor me before the elders of my people and before Israel. Go back with me so I may worship the Lord your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Samuel followed Saul back, and Saul worshiped the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel said, “Bring me King Agag of the Amalekites.” So Agag came to him trembling, thinking to himself, “Surely death is bitter!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said, “Just as your sword left women childless, so your mother will be the most bereaved among women.” Then Samuel hacked Agag to pieces there in Gilgal before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel went to Ramah, while Saul went up to his home in Gibeah of Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Until the day he died, Samuel did not see Saul again. Samuel did, however, mourn for Saul, but the Lord regretted that he had made Saul king over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Samuel, “How long do you intend to mourn for Saul? I have rejected him as king over Israel. Fill your horn with olive oil and go. I am sending you to Jesse in Bethlehem, for I have selected a king for myself from among his sons.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel replied, “How can I go? Saul will hear about it and kill me!” But the Lord said, “Take a heifer with you and say, ‘I have come to sacrifice to the Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then invite Jesse to the sacrifice, and I will show you what you should do. You will anoint for me the one I point out to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel did what the Lord told him. When he arrived in Bethlehem, the elders of the city were afraid to meet him. They said, “Do you come in peace?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, “Yes, in peace. I have come to sacrifice to the Lord. Consecrate yourselves and come with me to the sacrifice.” So he consecrated Jesse and his sons and invited them to the sacrifice.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they arrived, Samuel noticed Eliab and said to himself, “Surely, here before the Lord stands his chosen king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord said to Samuel, “Don’t be impressed by his appearance or his height, for I have rejected him. God does not view things the way people do. People look on the outward appearance, but the Lord looks at the heart.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesse called Abinadab and presented him to Samuel. But Samuel said, “The Lord has not chosen this one either.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesse presented Shammah. But Samuel said, “The Lord has not chosen this one either.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesse presented seven of his sons to Samuel. But Samuel said to Jesse, “The Lord has not chosen any of these.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel asked Jesse, “Is that all the young men?” Jesse replied, “There is still the youngest one, but he’s taking care of the flock.” Samuel said to Jesse, “Send and get him, for we cannot turn our attention to other things until he comes here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jesse had him brought in. Now he was ruddy, with attractive eyes and a handsome appearance. The Lord said, “Go and anoint him. This is the one.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Samuel took the horn full of olive oil and anointed him in the presence of his brothers. The Spirit of the Lord rushed upon David from that day onward. Then Samuel got up and went to Ramah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Spirit of the Lord had turned away from Saul, and an evil spirit from the Lord tormented him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul’s servants said to him, “Look, an evil spirit from God is tormenting you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let our lord instruct his servants who are here before you to look for a man who knows how to play the lyre. Then whenever the evil spirit from God comes upon you, he can play the lyre and you will feel better.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul said to his servants, “Find me a man who plays well and bring him to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One of his attendants replied, “I have seen a son of Jesse in Bethlehem who knows how to play the lyre. He is a brave warrior and is articulate and handsome, for the Lord is with him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul sent messengers to Jesse and said, “Send me your son David, who is out with the sheep.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jesse took a donkey loaded with bread, a container of wine, and a young goat and sent them to Saul with his son David.
speaker: Narrator

text: David came to Saul and stood before him. Saul liked him a great deal, and he became his armor-bearer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul sent word to Jesse saying, “Let David be my servant, for I am very pleased with him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So whenever the spirit from God would come upon Saul, David would take his lyre and play it. This would bring relief to Saul and make him feel better. Then the evil spirit would leave him alone.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines gathered their troops for battle. They assembled at Socoh in Judah. They camped in Ephes Dammim, between Socoh and Azekah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul and the Israelite army assembled and camped in the valley of Elah, where they arranged their battle lines to fight against the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines were standing on one hill, and the Israelites on another hill, with the valley between them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a champion came out from the camp of the Philistines. His name was Goliath; he was from Gath. He was close to seven feet tall.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had a bronze helmet on his head and was wearing scale body armor. The weight of his bronze body armor was 5,000 shekels.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had bronze shin guards on his legs, and a bronze javelin was slung over his shoulders.
speaker: Narrator

text: The shaft of his spear was like a weaver’s beam, and the iron point of his spear weighed 600 shekels. His shield bearer was walking before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Goliath stood and called to Israel’s troops, “Why do you come out to prepare for battle? Am I not the Philistine, and are you not the servants of Saul? Choose for yourselves a man so he may come down to me!
speaker: Narrator

text: If he is able to fight with me and strike me down, we will become your servants. But if I prevail against him and strike him down, you will become our servants and will serve us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Philistine said, “I defy Israel’s troops this day! Give me a man so we can fight each other!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul and all the Israelites heard these words of the Philistine, they were upset and very afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now David was the son of an Ephrathite named Jesse from Bethlehem in Judah. He had eight sons, and in Saul’s days he was old and well advanced in years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesse’s three oldest sons had followed Saul to war. The names of the three sons who went to war were Eliab, his firstborn, Abinadab, the second oldest; and Shammah, the third oldest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now David was the youngest. While the three oldest sons followed Saul,
speaker: Narrator

text: David was going back and forth from Saul in order to care for his father’s sheep in Bethlehem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile for forty days the Philistine approached every morning and evening and took his position.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesse said to his son David, “Take your brothers this ephah of roasted grain and these ten loaves of bread; go quickly to the camp to your brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also take these ten portions of cheese to their commanding officer. Find out how your brothers are doing and bring back their pledge that they received the goods.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are with Saul and the whole Israelite army in the valley of Elah, fighting with the Philistines.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David got up early in the morning and entrusted the flock to someone else who would watch over it. After loading up, he went just as Jesse had instructed him. He arrived at the camp as the army was going out to the battle lines shouting its battle cry.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel and the Philistines drew up their battle lines opposite one another.
speaker: Narrator

text: After David had entrusted his cargo to the care of the supply officer, he ran to the battlefront. When he arrived, he asked his brothers how they were doing.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he was speaking with them, the champion named Goliath, the Philistine from Gath, was coming up from the battle lines of the Philistines. He spoke the way he usually did, and David heard it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the men of Israel saw this man, they retreated from his presence and were very afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Israel said, “Have you seen this man who is coming up? He does so to defy Israel. But the king will make the man who can strike him down very wealthy! He will give him his daughter in marriage, and he will make his father’s house exempt from tax obligations in Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David asked the men who were standing near him, “What will be done for the man who strikes down this Philistine and frees Israel from this humiliation? For who is this uncircumcised Philistine, that he defies the armies of the living God?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The soldiers told him what had been promised, saying, “This is what will be done for the man who can strike him down.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When David’s oldest brother Eliab heard him speaking to the men, he became angry with David and said, “Why have you come down here? To whom did you entrust those few sheep in the wilderness? I am familiar with your pride and deceit! You have come down here to watch the battle.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David replied, “What have I done now? Can’t I say anything?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he turned from those who were nearby to someone else and asked the same question, but they gave him the same answer as before.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David’s words were overheard and reported to Saul, he called for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Saul, “Don’t let anyone be discouraged. Your servant will go and fight this Philistine!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Saul replied to David, “You aren’t able to go against this Philistine and fight him. You’re just a boy! He has been a warrior from his youth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David replied to Saul, “Your servant has been a shepherd for his father’s flock. Whenever a lion or bear would come and carry off a sheep from the flock,
speaker: Narrator

text: I would go out after it, strike it down, and rescue the sheep from its mouth. If it rose up against me, I would grab it by its jaw, strike it, and kill it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your servant has struck down both the lion and the bear. This uncircumcised Philistine will be just like one of them, for he has defied the armies of the living God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David went on to say, “The Lord who delivered me from the lion and the bear will also deliver me from the hand of this Philistine.” Then Saul said to David, “Go! The Lord will be with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul clothed David with his own fighting attire and put a bronze helmet on his head. He also put body armor on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: David strapped on his sword over his fighting attire and tried to walk around, but he was not used to them. David said to Saul, “I can’t walk in these things, for I’m not used to them.” So David removed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took his staff in his hand, picked out five smooth stones from the stream, placed them in the pouch of his shepherd’s bag, took his sling in hand, and approached the Philistine.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistine, with his shield bearer walking in front of him, kept coming closer to David.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Philistine looked carefully at David, he despised him, for he was only a ruddy and handsome boy.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistine said to David, “Am I a dog, that you are coming after me with sticks?” Then the Philistine cursed David by his gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistine said to David, “Come here to me, so I can give your flesh to the birds of the sky and the wild animals of the field!”
speaker: Narrator
