text: But David replied to the Philistine, “You are coming against me with sword and spear and javelin. But I am coming against you in the name of the Lord of Heaven’s Armies, the God of Israel’s armies, whom you have defied!
speaker: Narrator

text: This very day the Lord will deliver you into my hand. I will strike you down and cut off your head. This day I will give the corpses of the Philistine army to the birds of the sky and the wild animals of the land. Then all the land will realize that Israel has a God,
speaker: Narrator

text: and all this assembly will know that it is not by sword or spear that the Lord saves! For the battle is the Lord’s, and he will deliver you into our hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistine drew steadily closer to David to attack him, while David quickly ran toward the battle line to attack the Philistine.
speaker: Narrator

text: David reached his hand into the bag and took out a stone. He slung it, striking the Philistine on the forehead. The stone sank deeply into his forehead, and he fell down with his face to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: David prevailed over the Philistine with just the sling and the stone. He struck down the Philistine and killed him. David did not even have a sword in his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: David ran and stood over the Philistine. He grabbed Goliath’s sword, drew it from its sheath, and after killing him, he cut off his head with it. When the Philistines saw their champion was dead, they ran away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the men of Israel and Judah charged forward, shouting a battle cry. They chased the Philistines to the valley and to the very gates of Ekron. The Philistine corpses lay fallen along the Shaaraim road to Gath and Ekron.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Israelites returned from their hot pursuit of the Philistines, they looted their camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: David took the head of the Philistine and brought it to Jerusalem, and he put Goliath’s weapons in his tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now as Saul watched David going out to fight the Philistine, he asked Abner, the general in command of the army, “Whose son is that young man, Abner?” Abner replied, “As surely as you live, O king, I don’t know.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said, “Find out whose son this boy is.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So when David returned from striking down the Philistine, Abner took him and brought him before Saul. He still had the head of the Philistine in his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said to him, “Whose son are you, young man?” David replied, “I am the son of your servant Jesse in Bethlehem.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When David had finished talking with Saul, Jonathan and David became bound together in close friendship. Jonathan loved David as much as he did his own life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul retained David on that day and did not allow him to return to his father’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan made a covenant with David, for he loved him as much as he did his own life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan took off the robe he was wearing and gave it to David, along with the rest of his gear including his sword, his bow, and even his belt.
speaker: Narrator

text: On every mission on which Saul sent him, David achieved success. So Saul appointed him over the men of war. This pleased not only all the army, but also Saul’s servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the men arrived after David returned from striking down the Philistine, the women from all the cities of Israel came out singing and dancing to meet King Saul. They were happy as they played their tambourines and three-stringed instruments.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The women who were playing the music sang,
“Saul has struck down his thousands,
but David his tens of thousands!”
speaker: Narrator

text: This made Saul very angry. The statement displeased him and he thought, “They have attributed to David tens of thousands, but to me they have attributed only thousands. What does he lack, except the kingdom?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul was keeping an eye on David from that day onward.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day an evil spirit from God rushed upon Saul and he prophesied within his house. Now David was playing the lyre as usual. There was a spear in Saul’s hand,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Saul threw the spear, thinking, “I’ll nail David to the wall!” But David escaped from him on two different occasions.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul feared David, because the Lord was with David but had departed from Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul removed David from his presence and made him a commanding officer. David led the army out to battle and back.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now David achieved success in all he did, for the Lord was with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul saw how very successful he was, he was afraid of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But all Israel and Judah loved David, for he was the one leading them out to battle and back.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul said to David, “Here’s my oldest daughter, Merab. I want to give her to you in marriage. Only be a brave warrior for me and fight the battles of the Lord.” For Saul thought, “There’s no need for me to raise my hand against him. Let it be the hand of the Philistines!”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Saul, “Who am I? Who are my relatives or the clan of my father in Israel that I should become the king’s son-in-law?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the time came for Merab, Saul’s daughter, to be given to David, she instead was given in marriage to Adriel, who was from Meholah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Michal, Saul’s daughter, loved David. When they told Saul about this, it pleased him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said, “I will give her to him so that she may become a snare to him and so the hand of the Philistines may be against him.” So Saul said to David, “Today is the second time for you to become my son-in-law.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul instructed his servants, “Tell David secretly, ‘The king is pleased with you, and all his servants like you. So now become the king’s son-in-law.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul’s servants spoke these words privately to David. David replied, “Is becoming the king’s son-in-law something insignificant to you? I’m just a poor and lightly esteemed man!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul’s servants reported what David had said,
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul replied, “Here is what you should say to David: ‘There is nothing that the king wants as a price for the bride except 100 Philistine foreskins, so that he can be avenged of his enemies.’” (Now Saul was thinking that he could kill David by the hand of the Philistines.)
speaker: Narrator

text: So his servants told David these things and David agreed to become the king’s son-in-law. Now the specified time had not yet expired
speaker: Narrator

text: when David, along with his men, went out and struck down 200 Philistine men. David brought their foreskins and presented all of them to the king so that he could become the king’s son-in-law. Saul then gave him his daughter Michal in marriage.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul realized that the Lord was with David and that his daughter Michal loved David,
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul became even more afraid of him. Saul continued to be at odds with David from then on.
speaker: Narrator

text: The leaders of the Philistines would march out, and as often as they did so, David achieved more success than all of Saul’s servants. His name was held in high esteem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul told his son Jonathan and all his servants to kill David. But Saul’s son Jonathan liked David very much.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jonathan told David, “My father Saul is trying to kill you. So be careful tomorrow morning. Find a hiding place and stay in seclusion.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will go out and stand beside my father in the field where you are. I will speak to my father about you. When I find out what the problem is, I will let you know.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jonathan spoke on David’s behalf to his father Saul. He said to him, “The king should not sin against his servant David, for he has not sinned against you. On the contrary, his actions have been very beneficial for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: He risked his life when he struck down the Philistine, and the Lord gave all Israel a great victory. When you saw it, you were happy. So why would you sin against innocent blood by putting David to death for no reason?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul accepted Jonathan’s advice and took an oath, “As surely as the Lord lives, he will not be put to death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jonathan called David and told him all these things. Jonathan brought David to Saul, and he served him as he had done formerly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now once again there was war. So David went out to fight the Philistines. He defeated them thoroughly, and they ran away from him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then an evil spirit from the Lord came upon Saul. He was sitting in his house with his spear in his hand, while David was playing the lyre.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul tried to nail David to the wall with the spear, but he escaped from Saul’s presence, and the spear drove into the wall. David escaped quickly that night.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul sent messengers to David’s house to guard it and to kill him in the morning. Then David’s wife Michal told him, “If you do not save yourself tonight, tomorrow you will be dead!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Michal lowered David through the window, and he ran away and escaped.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Michal took a household idol and put it on the bed. She put a quilt made of goats’ hair over its head and then covered the idol with a garment.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul sent messengers to arrest David, she said, “He’s sick.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul sent the messengers back to see David, saying, “Bring him up to me on his bed so I can kill him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the messengers came, they found only the idol on the bed and the quilt made of goats’ hair at its head.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said to Michal, “Why have you deceived me this way by sending my enemy away? Now he has escaped!” Michal replied to Saul, “He said to me, ‘Help me get away or else I will kill you!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now David had run away and escaped. He went to Samuel in Ramah and told him everything that Saul had done to him. Then he and Samuel went and stayed at Naioth.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was reported to Saul saying, “David is at Naioth in Ramah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul sent messengers to capture David. When they saw a company of prophets prophesying with Samuel standing there as their leader, the Spirit of God came upon Saul’s messengers, and they also prophesied.
speaker: Narrator

text: When it was reported to Saul, he sent more messengers, but they prophesied too. So Saul sent messengers a third time, but they also prophesied.
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally Saul himself went to Ramah. When he arrived at the large cistern that is in Secu, he asked, “Where are Samuel and David?” They said, “At Naioth in Ramah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul went to Naioth in Ramah. The Spirit of God came upon him as well, and he walked along prophesying until he came to Naioth in Ramah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He even stripped off his clothes and prophesied before Samuel. He lay there naked all that day and night. (For that reason it is asked, “Is Saul also among the prophets?”)
speaker: Narrator

text: David fled from Naioth in Ramah. He came to Jonathan and asked, “What have I done? What is my offense? How have I sinned before your father, that he is seeking my life?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan said to him, “By no means are you going to die! My father does nothing large or small without making me aware of it. Why would my father hide this matter from me? It just won’t happen!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Taking an oath, David again said, “Your father is very much aware of the fact that I have found favor with you, and he has thought, ‘Don’t let Jonathan know about this, or he will be upset.’ But as surely as the Lord lives and you live, there is about one step between me and death!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan replied to David, “Tell me what I can do for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Jonathan, “Tomorrow is the new moon, and I am certainly expected to join the king for a meal. You must send me away so I can hide in the field until the third evening from now.
speaker: Narrator

text: If your father happens to miss me, you should say, ‘David urgently requested me to let him go to his town Bethlehem, for there is an annual sacrifice there for his entire family.’
speaker: Narrator

text: If he should then say, ‘That’s fine,’ then your servant is safe. But if he becomes very angry, be assured that he has decided to harm me.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must be loyal to your servant, for you have made a covenant with your servant in the Lord’s name. If I am guilty, you yourself kill me! Why bother taking me to your father?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan said, “Far be it from you to suggest this! If I were at all aware that my father had decided to harm you, wouldn’t I tell you about it?”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Jonathan, “Who will tell me if your father answers you harshly?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jonathan said to David, “Come on. Let’s go out to the field.”
When the two of them had gone out into the field,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan said to David, “The Lord God of Israel is my witness! I will feel out my father about this time the day after tomorrow. If he is favorably inclined toward David, will I not then send word to you and let you know?
speaker: Narrator

text: But if my father intends to do you harm, may the Lord do all this and more to Jonathan, if I don’t let you know and send word to you, so you can go safely on your way. May the Lord be with you, as he was with my father.
speaker: Narrator

text: While I am still alive, extend to me the loyalty of the Lord, or else I will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t ever cut off your loyalty to my family, not even when the Lord has cut off every one of David’s enemies from the face of the earth
speaker: Narrator

text: and called David’s enemies to account.” So Jonathan made a covenant with the house of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan once again took an oath with David, because he loved him. In fact Jonathan loved him as much as he did his own life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan said to him, “Tomorrow is the new moon, and you will be missed, for your seat will be empty.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the third day you should go down quickly and come to the place where you hid yourself the day this all started. Stay near the stone Ezel.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will shoot three arrows near it, as though I were shooting at a target.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I send a boy after them, I will say, ‘Go and find the arrows.’ If I say to the boy, ‘Look, the arrows are on this side of you; get them,’ then come back. For as surely as the Lord lives, you will be safe and there will be no problem.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if I say to the boy, ‘Look, the arrows are on the other side of you,’ then get away. For in that case the Lord has sent you away.
speaker: Narrator

text: With regard to the matter that you and I discussed, the Lord is the witness between us forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David hid in the field. When the new moon came, the king sat down to eat his meal.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king sat down in his usual place by the wall, with Jonathan opposite him and Abner at his side. But David’s place was vacant.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, Saul said nothing about it that day, for he thought, “Something has happened to make him ceremonially unclean. Yes, he must be unclean.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the next morning, the second day of the new moon, David’s place was still vacant. So Saul said to his son Jonathan, “Why has Jesse’s son not come to the meal yesterday or today?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan replied to Saul, “David urgently requested that he be allowed to go to Bethlehem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, ‘Permit me to go, for we are having a family sacrifice in the town, and my brother urged me to be there. So now, if I have found favor with you, let me go to see my brothers.’ For that reason he has not come to the king’s table.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul became angry with Jonathan and said to him, “You stupid traitor! Don’t I realize that to your own disgrace and to the disgrace of your mother’s nakedness you have chosen this son of Jesse?
speaker: Narrator

text: For as long as this son of Jesse is alive on the earth, you and your kingdom will not be established. Now, send some men and bring him to me. For he is as good as dead!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan responded to his father Saul, “Why should he be put to death? What has he done?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul threw his spear at Jonathan in order to strike him down. So Jonathan was convinced that his father had decided to kill David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan got up from the table enraged. He did not eat any food on that second day of the new moon, for he was upset that his father had humiliated David.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next morning Jonathan, along with a young servant, went out to the field to meet David.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to his servant, “Run, find the arrows that I am about to shoot.” As the servant ran, Jonathan shot the arrow beyond him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the servant came to the place where Jonathan had shot the arrow, Jonathan called out to the servant, “Isn’t the arrow farther beyond you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan called out to the servant, “Hurry! Go faster! Don’t delay!” Jonathan’s servant retrieved the arrow and came back to his master.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Now the servant did not understand any of this. Only Jonathan and David knew what was going on.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jonathan gave his equipment to the servant who was with him. He said to him, “Go, take these things back to the town.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the servant had left, David got up from beside the mound, knelt with his face to the ground, and bowed three times. Then they kissed each other and they both wept, especially David.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jonathan said to David, “Go in peace, for the two of us have sworn together in the name of the Lord saying, ‘The Lord will be between me and you and between my descendants and your descendants forever.’”
(21:1) Then David got up and left, while Jonathan went back to the town of Naioth.
speaker: Narrator

text: (21:2) David went to Ahimelech the priest in Nob. Ahimelech was shaking with fear when he met David, and said to him, “Why are you by yourself with no one accompanying you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: David replied to Ahimelech the priest, “The king instructed me to do something, but he said to me, ‘Don’t let anyone know the reason I am sending you or the instructions I have given you.’ I have told my soldiers to wait at a certain place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now what do you have at your disposal? Give me five loaves of bread, or whatever can be found.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest replied to David, “I don’t have any ordinary bread at my disposal. Only holy bread is available, and then only if your soldiers have abstained from relations with women.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to the priest, “Certainly women have been kept away from us, just as on previous occasions when I have set out. The soldiers’ equipment is holy, even on an ordinary journey. How much more so will they be holy today, along with their equipment!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the priest gave him holy bread, for there was no bread there other than the Bread of the Presence. It had been removed from before the Lord in order to replace it with hot bread on the day it had been taken away.
speaker: Narrator

text: (One of Saul’s servants was there that day, detained before the Lord. His name was Doeg the Edomite, who was in charge of Saul’s shepherds.)
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Ahimelech, “Is there no sword or spear here at your disposal? I don’t have my own sword or equipment in hand due to the urgency of the king’s instructions.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest replied, “The sword of Goliath the Philistine, whom you struck down in the valley of Elah, is wrapped in a garment behind the ephod. If you wish, take it for yourself. Other than that one, there’s no sword here.” David said, “There’s nothing like it. Give it to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So on that day David arose and fled from Saul. He went to King Achish of Gath.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The servants of Achish said to him, “Isn’t this David, the king of the land? Isn’t he the one that they sing about when they dance, saying,
‘Saul struck down his thousands,
but David his tens of thousands’?”
speaker: Narrator

text: David thought about what they said and was very afraid of King Achish of Gath.
speaker: Narrator

text: He altered his behavior in their presence. Since he was in their power, he pretended to be insane, making marks on the doors of the gate and letting his saliva run down his beard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Achish said to his servants, “Look at this madman! Why did you bring him to me?
speaker: Narrator

text: Do I have a shortage of fools so that you have brought me this man to display his insanity in front of me? Should this man enter my house?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David left there and escaped to the cave of Adullam. When his brothers and the rest of his father’s family learned about it, they went down there to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: All those who were in trouble or owed someone money or were discontented gathered around him, and he became their leader. He had about 400 men with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David went from there to Mizpah in Moab, where he said to the king of Moab, “Please let my father and mother stay with you until I know what God is going to do for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he had them stay with the king of Moab; they stayed with him the whole time that David was in the stronghold.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Gad the prophet said to David, “Don’t stay in the stronghold. Go to the land of Judah.” So David left and went to the forest of Hereth.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Saul found out the whereabouts of David and the men who were with him. Now Saul was sitting at Gibeah under the tamarisk tree at an elevated location with his spear in hand and all his servants stationed around him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said to his servants, “Listen up, you Benjaminites! Is Jesse’s son giving fields and vineyards to all of you? Or is he making all of you commanders and officers?
speaker: Narrator

text: For all of you have conspired against me! No one informs me when my own son makes an agreement with the son of Jesse. Not one of you feels sorry for me or informs me that my own son has commissioned my own servant to hide in ambush against me, as is the case today!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Doeg the Edomite, who had stationed himself with the servants of Saul, replied, “I saw this son of Jesse come to Ahimelech son of Ahitub at Nob.
speaker: Narrator

text: He inquired of the Lord for him and gave him provisions. He also gave him the sword of Goliath the Philistine.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king arranged for a meeting with the priest Ahimelech son of Ahitub and all the priests of his father’s house who were at Nob. They all came to the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul said, “Listen, son of Ahitub.” He replied, “Here I am, my lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said to him, “Why have you conspired against me, you and this son of Jesse? You gave him bread and a sword and inquired of God on his behalf, so that he opposes me and waits in ambush, as is the case today!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahimelech replied to the king, “Who among all your servants is faithful like David? He is the king’s son-in-law, the leader of your bodyguard, and honored in your house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Was it just today that I began to inquire of God on his behalf? Far be it from me! The king should not accuse his servant or any of my father’s house, for your servant is not aware of all this—not in whole or in part!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the king said, “You will surely die, Ahimelech, you and all your father’s house!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king said to the messengers who were stationed beside him, “Turn and kill the priests of the Lord, for they too have sided with David. They knew he was fleeing, but they did not inform me.” But the king’s servants refused to harm the priests of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king said to Doeg, “You turn and strike down the priests!” So Doeg the Edomite turned and struck down the priests. He killed on that day eighty-five men who wore the linen ephod.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for Nob, the city of the priests, Doeg struck down men and women, children and infants, oxen, donkeys, and sheep—all with the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: But one of the sons of Ahimelech son of Ahitub escaped and fled to David. His name was Abiathar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abiathar told David that Saul had killed the priests of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David said to Abiathar, “I knew that day when Doeg the Edomite was there that he would certainly tell Saul! I am guilty of all the deaths in your father’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Stay with me. Don’t be afraid. Whoever seeks my life is seeking your life as well. You are secure with me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They told David, “The Philistines are fighting in Keilah and are looting the threshing floors.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David asked the Lord, “Should I go and strike down these Philistines?” The Lord said to David, “Go, strike down the Philistines and deliver Keilah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But David’s men said to him, “We are afraid while we are still here in Judah. What will it be like if we go to Keilah against the armies of the Philistines?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David asked the Lord once again. But again the Lord replied, “Arise, go down to Keilah, for I will give the Philistines into your hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David and his men went to Keilah and fought the Philistines. He took away their cattle and thoroughly defeated them. David delivered the inhabitants of Keilah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when Abiathar son of Ahimelech had fled to David at Keilah, he had brought with him an ephod.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul was told that David had come to Keilah, Saul said, “God has delivered him into my hand, for he has boxed himself into a corner by entering a city with two barred gates.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul mustered all his army to go down to Keilah and besiege David and his men.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David realized that Saul was planning to harm him, he told Abiathar the priest, “Bring the ephod.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David said, “O Lord God of Israel, your servant has clearly heard that Saul is planning to come to Keilah to destroy the city because of me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will the leaders of Keilah deliver me into his hand? Will Saul come down as your servant has heard? O Lord God of Israel, please inform your servant.”
Then the Lord said, “He will come down.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David asked, “Will the leaders of Keilah deliver me and my men into Saul’s hand?” The Lord said, “They will deliver you over.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David and his men, who numbered about 600, set out and left Keilah; they moved around from one place to another. When told that David had escaped from Keilah, Saul called a halt to his expedition.
speaker: Narrator

text: David stayed in the strongholds that were in the desert and in the hill country of the wilderness of Ziph. Saul looked for him all the time, but God did not deliver David into his hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: David realized that Saul had come out to seek his life; at that time David was in Horesh in the wilderness of Ziph.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jonathan son of Saul left and went to David at Horesh. He encouraged him through God.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to him, “Don’t be afraid! For the hand of my father Saul cannot find you. You will rule over Israel, and I will be your second in command. Even my father Saul realizes this.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the two of them had made a covenant before the Lord, David stayed at Horesh, but Jonathan went to his house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Ziphites went up to Saul at Gibeah and said, “Isn’t David hiding among us in the strongholds at Horesh on the hill of Hakilah, south of Jeshimon?
speaker: Narrator

text: Now at your own discretion, O king, come down. Delivering him into the king’s hand will be our responsibility.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul replied, “May you be blessed by the Lord, for you have had compassion on me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go and make further arrangements. Determine precisely where he is and who has seen him there, for I am told that he is extremely cunning.
speaker: Narrator

text: Locate precisely all the places where he hides and return to me with dependable information. Then I will go with you. If he is in the land, I will find him among all the thousands of Judah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they left and went to Ziph ahead of Saul. Now David and his men were in the wilderness of Maon, in the rift valley to the south of Jeshimon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul and his men went to look for him. But David was informed and went down to the rock and stayed in the wilderness of Maon. When Saul heard about it, he pursued David in the wilderness of Maon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul went on one side of the mountain, while David and his men went on the other side of the mountain. David was hurrying to get away from Saul, but Saul and his men were surrounding David and his men to capture them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But a messenger came to Saul saying, “Come quickly, for the Philistines have raided the land!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul stopped pursuing David and went to confront the Philistines. Therefore that place is called Sela Hammahlekoth.
speaker: Narrator

text: (24:1) Then David went up from there and stayed in the strongholds of En Gedi.
speaker: Narrator

text: (24:2) When Saul returned from pursuing the Philistines, he was told, “Look, David is in the desert of En Gedi.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul took 3,000 select men from all Israel and went to find David and his men in the region of the rocks of the mountain goats.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He came to the sheepfolds by the road, where there was a cave. Saul went into it to relieve himself.
Now David and his men were sitting in the recesses of the cave.
speaker: Narrator

text: David’s men said to him, “This is the day about which the Lord said to you, ‘I will give your enemy into your hand, and you can do to him whatever seems appropriate to you.’” So David got up and quietly cut off an edge of Saul’s robe.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterward David’s conscience bothered him because he had cut off an edge of Saul’s robe.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to his men, “May the Lord keep me far away from doing such a thing to my lord, who is the Lord’s chosen one, by extending my hand against him. After all, he is the Lord’s chosen one.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David restrained his men with these words and did not allow them to rise up against Saul. Then Saul left the cave and started down the road.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterward David got up and went out of the cave. He called out to Saul, “My lord, O king!” When Saul looked behind him, David kneeled down and bowed with his face to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Saul, “Why do you pay attention when men say, ‘David is seeking to do you harm’?
speaker: Narrator

text: Today your own eyes see how the Lord delivered you—this very day—into my hands in the cave. Some told me to kill you, but I had pity on you and said, ‘I will not extend my hand against my lord, for he is the Lord’s chosen one.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, my father, and see the edge of your robe in my hand! When I cut off the edge of your robe, I didn’t kill you. So realize and understand that I am not planning evil or rebellion. Even though I have not sinned against you, you are waiting in ambush to take my life.
speaker: Narrator

text: May the Lord judge between the two of us, and may the Lord vindicate me over you, but my hand will not be against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: It’s like the old proverb says: ‘From evil people evil proceeds.’ But my hand will not be against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who has the king of Israel come out after? Who is it that you are pursuing? A dead dog? A single flea?
speaker: Narrator

text: May the Lord be our judge and arbiter. May he see and arbitrate my case and deliver me from your hands.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When David finished speaking these words to Saul, Saul said, “Is that your voice, my son David?” Then Saul wept loudly.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to David, “You are more innocent than I, for you have treated me well, even though I have tried to harm you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have explained today how you have treated me well. The Lord delivered me into your hand, but you did not kill me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if a man finds his enemy, does he send him on his way in good shape? May the Lord repay you with good this day for what you have done to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now look, I realize that you will in fact be king and that the kingdom of Israel will be established in your hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: So now swear to me in the Lord’s name that you will not kill my descendants after me or destroy my name from the house of my father.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David promised Saul this on oath. Then Saul went to his house, and David and his men went up to the stronghold.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel died, and all Israel assembled and mourned him. They buried him at his home in Ramah. Then David left and went down to the wilderness of Paran.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a man in Maon whose business was in Carmel. This man was very wealthy; he owned 3,000 sheep and 1,000 goats. At that time he was shearing his sheep in Carmel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man’s name was Nabal, and his wife’s name was Abigail. She was both wise and beautiful, but the man was harsh and his deeds were evil. He was a Calebite.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David heard in the wilderness that Nabal was shearing his sheep,
speaker: Narrator

text: he sent ten servants, saying to them, “Go up to Carmel to see Nabal and give him greetings in my name.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will say to my brother, ‘Peace to you and your house! Peace to all that is yours!
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I hear that they are shearing sheep for you. When your shepherds were with us, we neither insulted them nor harmed them the whole time they were in Carmel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ask your own servants; they can tell you! May my servants find favor in your sight, for we have come at the time of a holiday. Please provide us—your servants and your son David—with whatever you can spare.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David’s servants went and spoke all these words to Nabal in David’s name. Then they paused.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Nabal responded to David’s servants, “Who is David, and who is this son of Jesse? This is a time when many servants are breaking away from their masters!
speaker: Narrator

text: Should I take my bread and my water and my meat that I have slaughtered for my shearers and give them to these men? I don’t even know where they came from!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David’s servants went on their way. When they had returned, they came and told David all these things.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David instructed his men, “Each of you strap on your sword!” So each one strapped on his sword, and David also strapped on his sword. About 400 men followed David, while 200 stayed behind with the equipment.
speaker: Narrator

text: But one of the servants told Nabal’s wife Abigail, “David sent messengers from the wilderness to greet our lord, but he screamed at them.
speaker: Narrator

text: These men were very good to us. They did not insult us, nor did we sustain any loss during the entire time we were together in the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: Both night and day they were a protective wall for us the entire time we were with them, while we were tending our flocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now be aware of this, and see what you can do. For disaster has been planned for our lord and his entire household. He is such a wicked person that no one tells him anything!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abigail quickly took 200 loaves of bread, two containers of wine, five prepared sheep, five seahs of roasted grain, 100 bunches of raisins, and 200 lumps of pressed figs. She loaded them on donkeys
speaker: Narrator

text: and said to her servants, “Go on ahead of me. I will come after you.” But she did not tell her husband Nabal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Riding on her donkey, she went down under cover of the mountain. David and his men were coming down to meet her, and she encountered them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now David had been thinking, “In vain I guarded everything that belonged to this man in the wilderness. I didn’t take anything from him. But he has repaid my good with evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: God will severely punish David, if I leave alive until morning even one male from all those who belong to him!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Abigail saw David, she got down quickly from the donkey, threw herself facedown before David, and bowed to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Falling at his feet, she said, “My lord, I accept all the guilt! But please let your female servant speak to you! Please listen to the words of your servant!
speaker: Narrator

text: My lord should not pay attention to this wicked man Nabal. He simply lives up to his name! His name means ‘fool,’ and he is indeed foolish! But I, your servant, did not see the servants my lord sent.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now, my lord, as surely as the Lord lives and as surely as you live, it is the Lord who has kept you from shedding blood and taking matters into your own hands. Now may your enemies and those who seek to harm my lord be like Nabal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now let this present that your servant has brought to my lord be given to the servants who follow my lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Please forgive the sin of your servant, for the Lord will certainly establish a lasting dynasty for my lord, because my lord fights the battles of the Lord. May no evil be found in you all your days!
speaker: Narrator

text: When someone sets out to chase you and to take your life, the life of my lord will be wrapped securely in the bag of the living by the Lord your God. But he will sling away the lives of your enemies from the sling’s pocket!
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will do for my lord everything that he promised you, and he will make you a leader over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your conscience will not be overwhelmed with guilt for having poured out innocent blood and for having taken matters into your own hands. When the Lord has granted my lord success, please remember your servant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David said to Abigail, “Praised be the Lord, the God of Israel, who has sent you this day to meet me!
speaker: Narrator

text: Praised be your good judgment! May you yourself be rewarded for having prevented me this day from shedding blood and taking matters into my own hands!
speaker: Narrator

text: Otherwise, as surely as the Lord, the God of Israel, lives—he who has prevented me from harming you—if you had not come so quickly to meet me, by morning’s light not even one male belonging to Nabal would have remained alive!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David took from her hand what she had brought to him. He said to her, “Go back to your home in peace. Be assured that I have listened to you and responded favorably.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Abigail went back to Nabal, he was holding a banquet in his house like that of the king. Nabal was having a good time and was very intoxicated. She told him absolutely nothing until morning’s light.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning, when Nabal was sober, his wife told him about these matters. He had a stroke and was paralyzed.
speaker: Narrator

text: After about ten days the Lord struck Nabal down and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David heard that Nabal had died, he said, “Praised be the Lord who has vindicated me and avenged the insult that I suffered from Nabal! The Lord has kept his servant from doing evil, and he has repaid Nabal for his evil deeds.” Then David sent word to Abigail and asked her to become his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the servants of David went to Abigail at Carmel and said to her, “David has sent us to you to bring you back to be his wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She arose, bowed her face toward the ground, and said, “Your female servant, like a lowly servant, will wash the feet of the servants of my lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abigail quickly went and mounted her donkey, with five of her female servants accompanying her. She followed David’s messengers and became his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: David had also married Ahinoam from Jezreel; the two of them became his wives.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Now Saul had given his daughter Michal, David’s wife, to Paltiel son of Laish, who was from Gallim.)
speaker: Narrator

text: The Ziphites came to Saul at Gibeah and said, “Isn’t David hiding on the hill of Hakilah near Jeshimon?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul arose and went down to the wilderness of Ziph, accompanied by 3,000 select men of Israel, to look for David in the wilderness of Ziph.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul camped by the road on the hill of Hakilah near Jeshimon, but David was staying in the wilderness. When he realized that Saul had come to the wilderness to find him,
speaker: Narrator

text: David sent scouts and verified that Saul had indeed arrived.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David set out and went to the place where Saul was camped. David saw the place where Saul and Abner son of Ner, the general in command of his army, were sleeping. Now Saul was lying in the entrenchment, and the army was camped all around him.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Ahimelech the Hittite and Abishai son of Zeruiah, Joab’s brother, “Who will go down with me to Saul in the camp?” Abishai replied, “I will go down with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David and Abishai approached the army at night and found Saul lying asleep in the entrenchment with his spear stuck in the ground by his head. Abner and the army were lying all around him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abishai said to David, “Today God has delivered your enemy into your hands. Now let me drive the spear right through him into the ground with one swift jab! A second jab won’t be necessary!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But David said to Abishai, “Don’t kill him! Who can extend his hand against the Lord’s chosen one and remain guiltless?”
speaker: Narrator

text: David went on to say, “As the Lord lives, the Lord himself will strike him down. Either his day will come and he will die, or he will go down into battle and be swept away.
speaker: Narrator

text: But may the Lord prevent me from extending my hand against the Lord’s chosen one! Now take the spear by Saul’s head and the jug of water, and let’s get out of here!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David took the spear and the jug of water by Saul’s head, and they got out of there. No one saw them or was aware of their presence or woke up. All of them were asleep, for the Lord had caused a deep sleep to fall on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David crossed to the other side and stood on the top of the hill some distance away; there was a considerable distance between them.
speaker: Narrator

text: David called to the army and to Abner son of Ner, “Won’t you answer, Abner?” Abner replied, “Who are you, that you have called to the king?”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Abner, “Aren’t you a man? After all, who is like you in Israel? Why then haven’t you protected your lord the king? One of the soldiers came to kill your lord the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: This failure on your part isn’t good! As surely as the Lord lives, you people who have not protected your lord, the Lord’s chosen one, are as good as dead! Now look where the king’s spear and the jug of water that was by his head are!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul recognized David’s voice, he said, “Is that your voice, my son David?” David replied, “Yes, it’s my voice, my lord the king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He went on to say, “Why is my lord chasing his servant? What have I done? What wrong have I done?
speaker: Narrator

text: So let my lord the king now listen to the words of his servant. If the Lord has incited you against me, may he take delight in an offering. But if men have instigated this, may they be cursed before the Lord! For they have driven me away this day from being united with the Lord’s inheritance, saying, ‘Go on, serve other gods!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now don’t let my blood fall to the ground away from the Lord’s presence, for the king of Israel has gone out to look for a flea the way one looks for a partridge in the hill country.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul replied, “I have sinned. Come back, my son David. I won’t harm you anymore, for you treated my life with value this day. I have behaved foolishly and have made a very terrible mistake!”
speaker: Narrator

text: David replied, “Here is the king’s spear! Let one of your servants cross over and get it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord rewards each man for his integrity and loyalty. Even though today the Lord delivered you into my hand, I was not willing to extend my hand against the Lord’s chosen one.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way that I valued your life this day, may the Lord value my life and deliver me from all danger.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul replied to David, “May you be rewarded, my son David! You will without question be successful!” So David went on his way, and Saul returned to his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: David thought to himself, “One of these days I’m going to be swept away by the hand of Saul! There is nothing better for me than to escape to the land of the Philistines. Then Saul will despair of searching for me through all the territory of Israel and I will escape from his hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David left and crossed over to King Achish son of Maoch of Gath accompanied by his 600 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: David settled with Achish in Gath, along with his men and their families. David had with him his two wives, Ahinoam the Jezreelite and Abigail the Carmelite, Nabal’s widow.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul learned that David had fled to Gath, he did not mount a new search for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Achish, “If I have found favor with you, let me be given a place in one of the country towns so that I can live there. Why should your servant settle in the royal city with you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Achish gave him Ziklag on that day. (For that reason Ziklag has belonged to the kings of Judah until this very day.)
speaker: Narrator

text: The length of time that David lived in the Philistine countryside was a year and four months.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David and his men went up and raided the Geshurites, the Girzites, and the Amalekites. (They had been living in that land for a long time, from the approach to Shur as far as the land of Egypt.)
speaker: Narrator

text: When David would attack a district, he would leave neither man nor woman alive. He would take sheep, cattle, donkeys, camels, and clothing and would then go back to Achish.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Achish would ask, “Where did you raid today?” David would say, “The Negev of Judah” or “The Negev of Jerahmeel” or “The Negev of the Kenites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Neither man nor woman would David leave alive so as to bring them back to Gath. He was thinking, “This way they can’t tell on us, saying, ‘This is what David did.’” Such was his practice the entire time that he lived in the country of the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Achish trusted David, thinking to himself, “He is really hated among his own people in Israel! From now on he will be my servant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days the Philistines gathered their troops for war in order to fight Israel. Achish said to David, “You should fully understand that you and your men must go with me into the battle.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David replied to Achish, “That being the case, you will come to know what your servant can do!” Achish said to David, “Then I will make you my bodyguard from now on.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Samuel had died, and all Israel had lamented over him and had buried him in Ramah, his hometown. In the meantime Saul had removed the mediums and magicians from the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines assembled; they came and camped at Shunem. Saul mustered all Israel and camped at Gilboa.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul saw the camp of the Philistines, he was absolutely terrified.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul inquired of the Lord, but the Lord did not answer him—not by dreams nor by Urim nor by the prophets.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul instructed his servants, “Find me a woman who is a medium, so that I may go to her and inquire of her.” His servants replied to him, “There is a woman who is a medium in Endor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul disguised himself and put on other clothing and left, accompanied by two of his men. They came to the woman at night and said, “Use your ritual pit to conjure up for me the one I tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the woman said to him, “Look, you are aware of what Saul has done; he has removed the mediums and magicians from the land! Why are you trapping me so you can put me to death?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Saul swore an oath to her by the Lord, “As surely as the Lord lives, you will not incur guilt in this matter!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman replied, “Who is it that I should bring up for you?” He said, “Bring up for me Samuel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the woman saw Samuel, she cried out loudly. The woman said to Saul, “Why have you deceived me? You are Saul!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to her, “Don’t be afraid! But what have you seen?” The woman replied to Saul, “I have seen a divine being coming up from the ground!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said to her, “What about his appearance?” She said, “An old man is coming up! He is wrapped in a robe!”
Then Saul realized it was Samuel, and he bowed his face toward the ground and kneeled down.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said to Saul, “Why have you disturbed me by bringing me up?” Saul replied, “I am terribly troubled! The Philistines are fighting against me and God has turned away from me. He does not answer me anymore—not by the prophets nor by dreams. So I have called on you to tell me what I should do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said, “Why are you asking me, now that the Lord has turned away from you and has become your enemy?
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord has done exactly as I prophesied! The Lord has torn the kingdom from your hand and has given it to your neighbor David!
speaker: Narrator

text: Since you did not obey the Lord and did not carry out his fierce anger against the Amalekites, the Lord has done this thing to you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will hand you and Israel over to the Philistines! Tomorrow both you and your sons will be with me. The Lord will also hand the army of Israel over to the Philistines!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul quickly fell full length on the ground and was very afraid because of Samuel’s words. He was completely drained of energy, having not eaten anything all that day and night.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the woman came to Saul and saw how terrified he was, she said to him, “Your servant has done what you asked. I took my life into my own hands and did what you told me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now it’s your turn to listen to your servant! Let me set before you a bit of bread so that you can eat. When you regain your strength, you can go on your way.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he refused, saying, “I won’t eat!” Both his servants and the woman urged him to eat, so he gave in. He got up from the ground and sat down on the bed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the woman had a well-fed calf at her home that she quickly slaughtered. Taking some flour, she kneaded it and baked bread without leaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: She brought it to Saul and his servants, and they ate. Then they arose and left that same night.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines assembled all their troops at Aphek, while Israel camped at the spring that is in Jezreel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the leaders of the Philistines were passing in review at the head of their units of hundreds and thousands, David and his men were passing in review in the rear with Achish.
speaker: Narrator

text: The leaders of the Philistines asked, “What about these Hebrews?” Achish said to the leaders of the Philistines, “Isn’t this David, the servant of King Saul of Israel, who has been with me for quite some time? I have found no fault with him from the day of his defection until the present time!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the leaders of the Philistines became angry with him and said to him, “Send the man back! Let him return to the place that you assigned him! Don’t let him go down with us into the battle, for he might become our adversary in the battle. What better way to please his lord than with the heads of these men?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Isn’t this David, of whom they sang as they danced,
‘Saul has struck down his thousands,
but David his tens of thousands’?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Achish summoned David and said to him, “As surely as the Lord lives, you are an honest man, and I am glad to have you serving with me in the army. I have found no fault with you from the day that you first came to me until the present time. But in the opinion of the leaders, you are not reliable.
speaker: Narrator

text: So turn and leave in peace. You must not do anything that the leaders of the Philistines consider improper!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But David said to Achish, “What have I done? What have you found in your servant from the day that I first came into your presence until the present time, that I shouldn’t go and fight the enemies of my lord the king?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Achish replied to David, “I am convinced that you are as reliable as the angel of God! However, the leaders of the Philistines have said, ‘He must not go up with us in the battle.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So get up early in the morning along with the servants of your lord who have come with you. When you get up early in the morning, as soon as it is light enough to see, leave.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David and his men got up early in the morning to return to the land of the Philistines, but the Philistines went up to Jezreel.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the third day David and his men came to Ziklag. Now the Amalekites had raided the Negev and Ziklag. They attacked Ziklag and burned it.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took captive the women and all who were in it, from the youngest to the oldest, but they did not kill anyone. They simply carried them off and went on their way.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David and his men came to the city, they found it burned. Their wives, sons, and daughters had been taken captive.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David and the men who were with him wept loudly until they could weep no more.
speaker: Narrator

text: David’s two wives had been taken captive—Ahinoam the Jezreelite and Abigail the Carmelite, Nabal’s widow.
speaker: Narrator

text: David was very upset, for the men were thinking of stoning him; each man grieved bitterly over his sons and daughters. But David drew strength from the Lord his God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David said to the priest Abiathar son of Ahimelech, “Bring me the ephod.” So Abiathar brought the ephod to David.
speaker: Narrator

text: David inquired of the Lord, saying, “Should I pursue this raiding band? Will I overtake them?” He said to him, “Pursue, for you will certainly overtake them and carry out a rescue!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David went, accompanied by his 600 men. When he came to the Wadi Besor, those who were in the rear stayed there.
speaker: Narrator

text: David and 400 men continued the pursuit, but 200 men who were too exhausted to cross the Wadi Besor stayed there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they found an Egyptian in the field and brought him to David. They gave him bread to eat and water to drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: They gave him a slice of pressed figs and two bunches of raisins to eat. This greatly refreshed him, for he had not eaten food or drunk water for three days and three nights.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to him, “To whom do you belong, and where are you from?” The young man said, “I am an Egyptian, the servant of an Amalekite man. My master abandoned me when I was ill for three days.
speaker: Narrator

text: We conducted a raid on the Negev of the Kerethites, on the area of Judah, and on the Negev of Caleb. We burned Ziklag.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to him, “Can you take us down to this raiding party?” He said, “Swear to me by God that you will not kill me or hand me over to my master, and I will take you down to this raiding party.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he took David down, and they found them spread out over the land. They were eating and drinking and enjoying themselves because of all the loot they had taken from the land of the Philistines and from the land of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: But David struck them down from twilight until the following evening. None of them escaped, with the exception of 400 young men who got away on camels.
speaker: Narrator

text: David retrieved everything the Amalekites had taken; he also rescued his two wives.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was nothing missing, whether small or great. He retrieved sons and daughters, the plunder, and everything else they had taken. David brought everything back.
speaker: Narrator

text: David took all the flocks and herds and drove them in front of the rest of the animals. People were saying, “This is David’s plunder!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David approached the 200 men who had been too exhausted to go with him, those whom they had left at the Wadi Besor. They went out to meet David and the people who were with him. When David approached the people, he asked how they were doing.
speaker: Narrator

text: But all the evil and worthless men among those who had gone with David said, “Since they didn’t go with us, we won’t give them any of the loot we retrieved! They may take only their wives and children. Let them lead them away and be gone!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But David said, “No! You shouldn’t do this, my brothers. Look at what the Lord has given us! He has protected us and has delivered into our hands the raiding party that came against us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who will listen to you in this matter? The portion of the one who went down into the battle will be the same as the portion of the one who remained with the equipment! Let their portions be the same!”
speaker: Narrator

text: From that time onward it was a binding ordinance for Israel, right up to the present time.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David came to Ziklag, he sent some of the plunder to the elders of Judah who were his friends, saying, “Here’s a gift for you from the looting of the Lord’s enemies!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The gift was for those in the following locations: for those in Bethel, Ramoth Negev, and Jattir;
speaker: Narrator

text: for those in Aroer, Siphmoth, Eshtemoa,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Racal; for those in the cities of the Jerahmeelites and Kenites;
speaker: Narrator

text: for those in Hormah, Bor Ashan, Athach,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Hebron; and for those in whatever other places David and his men had traveled.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Philistines were fighting against Israel. The men of Israel fled from the Philistines and many of them fell dead on Mount Gilboa.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines stayed right on the heels of Saul and his sons. They struck down Saul’s sons Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malki-Shua.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul himself was in the thick of the battle; the archers spotted him and wounded him severely.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said to his armor-bearer, “Draw your sword and stab me with it! Otherwise these uncircumcised people will come, stab me, and torture me.” But his armor-bearer refused to do it, because he was very afraid. So Saul took his sword and fell on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When his armor-bearer saw that Saul was dead, he also fell on his own sword and died with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul, his three sons, his armor-bearer, and all his men died together that day.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the men of Israel who were in the valley and across the Jordan saw that the men of Israel had fled and that Saul and his sons were dead, they abandoned the cities and fled. The Philistines came and occupied them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day, when the Philistines came to strip loot from the corpses, they discovered Saul and his three sons lying dead on Mount Gilboa.
speaker: Narrator

text: They cut off Saul’s head and stripped him of his armor. They sent messengers to announce the news in the temple of their idols and among their people throughout the surrounding land of the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: They placed Saul’s armor in the temple of the Ashtoreths and hung his corpse on the city wall of Beth Shan.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the residents of Jabesh Gilead heard what the Philistines had done to Saul,
speaker: Narrator

text: all their warriors set out and traveled throughout the night. They took Saul’s corpse and the corpses of his sons from the city wall of Beth Shan and went to Jabesh, where they burned them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took the bones and buried them under the tamarisk tree at Jabesh; then they fasted for seven days.
speaker: Narrator
